abstract.text: 16 The virus receptors are key for the viral infection of host cells. Identification of the 17 virus receptors is still challenging at present. Our previous study has shown that 18 human virus receptor proteins have some unique features including high 19 N-glycosylation level, high number of interaction partners and high expression level. 20 Here, a random-forest model was built to identify human virus receptorome from 21 human cell membrane proteins with an accepted accuracy based on the combination 22 of the unique features of human virus receptors and protein sequences. A total of 1380 23 human cell membrane proteins were predicted to constitute the receptorome of the 24 human-infecting virome. In addition, the combination of the random-forest model 25 with protein-protein interactions between human and viruses predicted in previous 26 48 experimental methods have been developed for identifying virus receptors. The first 49 approach is to select candidate membrane proteins that can bind to the virus 50 receptor-binding proteins (RBPs) by affinity purification and mass spectroscopy (Free 51 et al., 2009; Ryu, 2016). The second approach is firstly to identify monoclonal 52 antibodies which can block the virus entry, and then take the membrane proteins to 53 which the monoclonal antibodies bind as candidate receptor proteins (Minor et al., 54 1984; Ryu, 2016). The third approach is to identify virus receptors by functional 55 cloning selection based on the cDNA expression library (Ryu, 2016). For example, Lasso et al. developed an in silico computational 66 framework (P-HIPSTer) that employed the structural information to predict more than 67 280,000 PPIs between 1,001 human-infecting viruses and humans, and made a series 68 of new findings about human-virus interactions (Lasso et al., 2019). The predicted 69 PPIs between viral RBPs and human cell membrane proteins can be used to identify 70 virus receptors. Here, a computational model was developed to predict the 71 receptorome of the human-infecting virome based on the features of human virus 72 receptors and protein sequences. Furthermore, the combination of this computational 73 model with the PPIs predicted in Lasso's work was further used to predict the 74 receptors for 693 human-infecting viruses. The results of this study would greatly 75 facilitate the identification of human virus receptors.

MACV, Machupo 269 mammarenavirus; HAdV-A, Human mastadenovirus A; HAdV-C, Human 270 mastadenovirus C; HAdV-E, Human mastadenovirus E;HAdV-D, Human The identification of receptors for human-infecting viruses is critical for 276 understanding the interactions between viruses and human. Our previous studies have 277 shown that human virus receptor proteins have some unique features compared to 278 other cell membrane proteins, including high N-glycosylation level, high number of 279 interaction partners and high expression level. This study further built a RF model for 280 identifying human virus receptors from human cell membrane proteins with an 281 accepted accuracy. Based on the RF model, the receptorome for the human-infecting 282 virome was predicted, which included a total of 1380 human cell membrane proteins. The results could facilitate the identification of human virus receptors. In the previous study, Lasso et al. developed a computational model for predicting PPIs between human-infecting viruses and human (Lasso et al., 2019). A variable 287 number of human cell membrane proteins were predicted to interact with viral RBPs. To further select the potential receptors for viruses, both the LR and the RF model 289 were used to rank the viral RBP-interacting human cell membrane proteins. The RF 290 model was found to rank the real receptors better than the LR in a small validation 291 dataset, suggesting that the performance of the RF model may be superior to that of 292 the LR in selecting the real receptors from the predicted RBP-interacting human cell 293 membrane proteins. The combination of the RF model and the RBP-interacting 294 human cell membrane proteins predicted in Lasso's work enabled the prediction of 295 receptors for 693 human-infecting viruses(Table S2). Nevertheless, more efforts are 296 needed to validate these candidate receptors in future studies.There are some limitations to this study. Firstly, the number of human virus receptor299    proteins was much smaller than that of human membrane proteins in the modeling, which may hinder accurate modeling. Thus, the under-sampling method was used to 301 deal with the imbalance problem. Secondly, the performance of the RF model was302 modest in discriminating human virus receptor proteins from human membrane 303 proteins. More efforts are still needed to improve the model. Thirdly, although the RF 304 model can be used to predict the receptorome of human-infecting virome, it is not 305 feasible to use the model to identify the receptors for a specific human-infecting virus. The combination of the RF model with the model of PPI predictions such as Lasso's 307 work can help identify virus-receptor interactions. In conclusion, this study for the first time built a computational model for predicting 310 the receptorome of the human-infecting virome.
